questions.text: CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. Single ipsilateral < 3cm node is seen. What is the staging? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. T4N1M0

The given CT image is consistent with a staging of T4N1M0. It depicts a large glottic-subglottic mass with massive cricoid and thyroid invasion and extra laryngeal spread indicating a T4 stage.

Above shown is CT scan of a 72-year-old patient with T4a laryngeal cancer (red arrows) showing a large extralaryngeal extension through the left side of the thyroid cartilage. Indication of primary total laryngectomy.

Other Options:

Option A. T1N0M0: Would indicate a tumor confined to one subsite with no lymph node involvement or distant metastasis, which does not correlate with the extensive involvement shown in the image.

Option C. T2N1M0: Suggests tumor involvement of adjacent subsites or impaired vocal cord mobility, which is less extensive than that shown.

Option D. T3N0M0: Indicates more advanced local disease than T2 but without the extensive extra-laryngeal spread or significant lymph node involvement shown in the image.

Educational Objective:

TNM STAGING FOR CA LARYNX:

T1 – Only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis)

T2 – Involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility.

T3 – Involving Pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords.

T4a – Local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx

T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc)

N0 – No cervical lymph nodes

N1 – Single ipsilateral < 3cm

N2 – Single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm

N3 – Single or multiple nodes > 6cm

M0 – No metastasis

M1 – Metastasis present

Ref: Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 348

questions.text: Endolymphatic hydrops is typically associated with which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Meniere's disease

 

Explanation: 

 

Endolymphatic hydrops is the pathophysiological basis of Meniere's disease. It is characterized by excessive accumulation of endolymph in the inner ear, causing distension of the membranous labyrinth. This directly correlates with the classic clinical symptoms seen in Meniere's disease: episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus and aural fullness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Otosclerosis: This is a condition with irregular spongy bone formation around the oval window, leading to fixation of the stapes footplate. It causes a conductive hearing loss due to impeded sound transmission. Otosclerosis has no relationship with endolymphatic hydrops or the balance mechanism.

 

Option C. Acoustic Neuroma: This is a benign tumor that arises from the inferior vestibular nerve in the internal auditory canal. It causes progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. It is not associated with endolymphatic hydrops or fluctuating symptoms like those seen in Meniere's disease.

 

Option D. Cholesteatoma: This is a "skin in the wrong place" - keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear cleft. It causes a destructive process in the middle ear with bone erosion and conductive hearing loss. It has no connection with endolymphatic hydrops.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Endolymphatic hydrops is the hallmark pathological finding in Meniere's disease, causing episodic symptoms of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and aural fullness due to increased pressure in the inner ear's endolymphatic system.

questions.text: Which perspective provides the clearest view of the frontal sinus? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Caldwell’s view

 

The Caldwell view is a caudally angled radiograph, with its posteroanterior projection allowing for minimal radiation to the orbits.

 

The rays pass from behind the head and are angled at 15-20° to the radiographic plate. It is commonly used to get better view of the ethmoid and frontal sinuses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Towne's View: Primarily used for examining the foramen magnum at the base of the skull, not ideal for sinus examination.

 

Option C. Law's View: Typically used for visualizing the mastoid air cells, not the frontal sinuses.

 

Option D. Stenver's View: Used for imaging the internal auditory canal and cochlea, not related to sinus imaging

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Stenver’s view is done for cochlear implants.

 

 

  • Law’s view is used to assess mastoid air cells.

 

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493, 494

questions.text: Carhart notch is seen in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Otosclerosis

 

Carhart's notch is a characteristic audiometric finding in otosclerosis where there is a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz (2 kHz) on pure tone audiometry. In otosclerosis, there is irregular spongy bone deposition in the anterior part of footplate and adjacent oval window (fissula ante fenestram), which impedes sound conduction and causes conductive hearing loss. When plotting an audiogram, the bone conduction curve shows this specific notch or dip at 2000 Hz, while the air conduction curve remains affected throughout, showing the conductive hearing loss pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sudden SNHL: Sudden sensorineural hearing loss shows a sudden drop in both air and bone conduction curves across all frequencies without any specific notch pattern at 2000 Hz.

 

Option C. Meniere's disease: In Meniere's disease, the audiogram typically shows a low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss with an up-sloping curve. There is no specific notch at 2000 Hz.

 

 

Option D. Acoustic neuroma: Acoustic neuroma typically shows a trough-shaped or cookie-bite audiogram pattern affecting the middle frequencies, but does not show the specific Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carhart's notch is a characteristic dip at 2000 Hz on the bone conduction curve in pure tone audiometry, specifically seen in otosclerosis.

 

Important points to remember on otoselerosis:

 

  • Most common site - Fissula ante fenestrum
  • Most common type- Stapedial
  • Other 2 type -Cochlear, Histologic
  • Clinical presentation - Hearing impairment
  • Paracusis willisii (hears better in noisy surroundngs)
  • Otoscopy - Intract tympanic membrane
  • Schwarts sign - Seen in active lesions only, reddish hue seen on promontory through intact TM
  • Tunning fork tests - Rinne negative, Weber to poorer ear → conductive loss
  • Pure tone audiometry -Dip at 2000Hz on BC curve (Carhart's notch)
  • Treatment of choice - Surgery (Stapedotomy > Stapedectomy)
  • Other treatments - NaF, Hearing aid for those not fit for surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

Since the tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve.

 

 

Referred causes of otalgia. Pain is referred via CN V (teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, anterior two-thirds of tongue), C2,3 (cervical spine), CN IX (tonsil, base of tongue, elongated styloid process) and CN X (vallecula, pyriform fossa or larynx).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial nerve - This nerve primarily deals with facial expressions and some sensory functions of the face, not typically involved in referred pain from tonsillitis to the ear.

 

Option C. Trigeminal nerve - While it is a significant sensory nerve for the face, it is more commonly associated with referred pain from the teeth, oral cavity, TM joint, and anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via CN V).

 

Option D. Vagus nerve - Involved in sensory functions from the base of the tongue, vallecula, pyriform fossa, and larynx, not directly involved in referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Referred otalgia from tonsillitis is most commonly mediated through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), highlighting the importance of the nerve's role in sensory transmission from the tonsils and tonsillar fossa to the ear.

 

Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 143, 144

questions.text: The radiograph presented below has been taken to enhance the evaluation of the frontal sinus. What is the widely used term for this particular perspective?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caldwell view

 

  • The above X ray shows the Caldwell view in which the frontal sinus is best seen.
  • Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is taken with nose and forehead touching the film and X-ray beam is projected 15–20° caudally.
  • Structures seen are:
    1. Frontal sinuses (Best Visualization).
    2. Ethmoid sinuses.
    3. Maxillary sinuses.
    4. Frontal process of zygoma and zygomatic process of frontal bone.
    5. Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea.
    6. Superior orbital fissure.
    7. Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water's view: Primarily used for examining the maxillary sinuses and can also show the frontal sinuses but with less clarity than the Caldwell view.

 

Option C. Pierre's view: This is not a standard term in radiographic terminology.

 

Option D. Towne's view: Used to visualize the occipital bone and foramen magnum, not typically used for sinus examination.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the part of the cochlear implant marked? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grounding electrode

 

 

The marked part in the image is the grounding electrode, also known as the reference electrode. In a cochlear implant, the grounding electrode is usually implanted in the temporalis area. Its primary function is to serve as a reference point for electrical signals, ensuring accurate signal transmission and reducing noise interference during the processing of sound signals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amplifier: An amplifier is not a distinct part of the cochlear implant. Instead, the sound processor amplifies and processes the sound signals before transmitting them to the receiver.

 

Option C. Receiver: The receiver in a cochlear implant is a component that lies under the skin and receives sound signals from the external transmitter. It is not the marked part in the image.

 

Option D. Electrode array: The electrode array is implanted inside the cochlea and is responsible for stimulating the auditory nerve. It directly interacts with the cochlea, unlike the grounding electrode that is positioned externally or at a different implant site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The grounding electrode or reference electrode in a cochlear implant is implanted in the temporalis area and is crucial for accurate signal transmission by providing a reference point for electrical signals.

questions.text: A female singer with hoarseness of voice, unable to sing higher frequency notes. Bowed and depressed unilateral vocal cord is seen. Which muscle is involved? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricothyroid

  

The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for tensing the vocal cords, which allows for the production of higher frequency sounds. When the vocal cords are tightly stretched, they vibrate at a higher frequency, which is necessary for producing high-pitched notes.

 

In this scenario, the female singer is unable to sing higher frequency notes, indicating that her vocal cords are not adequately tense. This suggests paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, which normally maintains the tension of the vocal cords. If the cricothyroid muscle is paralyzed, typically due to damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, the vocal cords become bowed, loose, and floppy, impairing the ability to produce high-frequency sounds.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cricoarytenoid: This muscle is the only abductor of the vocal cords, which means it separates the vocal cords during breathing. It does not contribute to tensing the vocal cords for high-frequency sound production.

 

Option B. Thyroarytenoid: This muscle acts as both an adductor and a relaxer of the vocal cords, contributing to lowering the pitch of the voice rather than raising it. It does not tense the vocal cords and, therefore, does not aid in the production of higher frequency notes.

 

Option D. Interarytenoid: This muscle functions as an adductor, helping to bring the vocal cords together. It does not have a role in tensing the vocal cords for higher frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cricothyroid muscle is essential for producing high-frequency notes by tensing the vocal cords. Paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle leads to the inability to produce these higher notes due to a lack of tension in the vocal cords.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with persistent nasal congestion, foul-smelling greenish-black nasal crusts, and anosmia. Examination reveals a dry nasal cavity with crust formation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests atrophic rhinitis. 

 

  • The presence of foul-smelling greenish-black discharge (due to Klebsiella ozaenae infection)
  • Anosmia (due to atrophy of nerve elements)
  • Crusting in nasal cavity (due to transformation of normal ciliated columnar epithelium to abnormal stratified squamous epithelium)
  • Female patient (consistent with demographics as atrophic rhinitis commonly affects females)
  • The disease process involves atrophy of nasal mucosa, leading to loss of defense mechanisms (cilia and mucous glands), resulting in secondary infections and crust formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhinoscleroma

 

  • While the first stage can mimic atrophic rhinitis, it typically doesn't present with anosmia
  • Characterized by painless nodules giving woody feel ("woody nose" or "hebra nose")
  • Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

 

 

Option C. Hypertrophic rhinitis

 

  • Presents with bilateral inferior turbinate hypertrophy
  • Shows mulberry appearance of turbinates
  • No crusting or anosmia

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis

 

  • Presents with sneezing, itching, and watery discharge
  • IgE-mediated type 1 hypersensitivity reaction
  • No foul smell or crusting
  • Typically shows pale, boggy mucosa

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic Rhinitis (Ozaenae)

choices.text: Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
Ossicular fixation without intact tympanic membrane

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented with hearing loss. On PTA, the amount of hearing loss was 56dB: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane

 

Otosclerosis is a common cause of progressive hearing loss, particularly in young adults and often worsens during pregnancy due to hormonal changes. The condition is characterized by abnormal bone growth around the stapes bone in the middle ear, leading to its fixation. This fixation prevents the stapes from vibrating in response to sound waves, thereby reducing the transmission of sound to the inner ear and causing hearing loss.

 

In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane (eardrum) typically appears normal upon examination. The hearing loss in otosclerosis is conductive, meaning it is due to a problem in the outer or middle ear, which transmits sound to the inner ear. A pure-tone audiogram (PTA) showing a 56dB hearing loss indicates significant conductive hearing impairment, consistent with otosclerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ossicular fixation without intact tympanic membrane: This condition is not typical of otosclerosis. Ossicular fixation in otosclerosis occurs with an intact tympanic membrane. A non-intact tympanic membrane would suggest a different pathology, such as chronic otitis media.

 

Option C. Erosion with intact tympanic membrane: Ossicular erosion with an intact tympanic membrane is not characteristic of otosclerosis. Ossicular erosion is more commonly seen in chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), particularly in its cholesteatoma form, which can erode the ossicles but usually involves perforation of the tympanic membrane.

 

Option D. Erosion without intact tympanic membrane: This is also not typical of otosclerosis. Erosion without an intact tympanic membrane again points towards chronic otitis media, especially with complications leading to ossicular erosion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otosclerosis often presents as progressive conductive hearing loss with an intact tympanic membrane, and the hearing loss can worsen during pregnancy. The classic finding is ossicular fixation, particularly of the stapes bone.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents in the ENT OPD with complaints of pain and discharge from the ear. Examination reveals the following findings. What is the best line of treatment? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clotrimazole ear drops

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with pain and discharge from the ear, and the examination shows black-headed filamentous growths on the otoendoscopic picture. This indicates a fungal infection, specifically otomycosis caused by Aspergillus niger. The best treatment for otomycosis is an antifungal agent.

 

Clotrimazole an antifungal and is typically used to treat otomycosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clotrimoxazole ear drops: Not an antifungal drug.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin ear drops: Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic and is used to treat bacterial infections. It does not have antifungal properties.

 

Option D. Wax softening ear drops: Wax softening ear drops contain ingredients like paradichlorobenzene, chlorbutol, and turpentine oil, which are used to soften ear wax. This treatment is irrelevant in the context of a fungal infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otomycosis, a fungal infection of the ear, caused by Aspergillus niger, should be treated with antifungal agents like Clotrimazole ear drops.

questions.text: The image of a drug is given below. It is used in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subglottic stenosis

 

The given drug is Mitomycin-C. It is used topically in the management of subglottic stenosis.

 

Mitomycin is an antibiotic that is isolated from the broth of Streptomyces caespitosus. This drug has demonstrated antitumor activity. Mitomycin belongs to a group of alkylating agents that work by cross-linking the complementary strands found in DNA. It also has antifibrotic property which prevents tissue scarring.

 

Thus, it can used to inhibit post-surgical scar formation and as a chemotherapeutic agent.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis - This fungal infection requires antifungal medications, not typically treated with Mitomycin-C.

 

Option C. Adenoidectomy - A surgical procedure to remove adenoids; does not involve the use of Mitomycin-C.

 

Option D. Tympanoplasty - Surgical repair of the eardrum, where Mitomycin-C is not routinely used.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Mitomycin-C is particularly effective in preventing the recurrence of subglottic stenosis after surgery due to its antifibrotic properties, making it a critical adjunct in surgical procedures involving the airway.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 3, Page No. 1088

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with nonaxial proptosis of the left eye. The patient gives a history of a road traffic accident 15 years back. The CT image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Frontal mucocele

 

The given clinical scenario and the image findings are suggestive of a frontal mucocele.

 

A frontal mucocele is a benign cystic lesion that develops in the frontal sinus, which is one of the air-filled spaces located in the forehead region of the skull. It typically occurs as a result of the blockage or obstruction of the frontal sinus drainage pathway, leading to the accumulation of mucus within the sinus cavity. Over time, the trapped mucus can cause the sinus walls to expand, forming a mucocele.

 

 

Patient presents with headache, diplopia, and proptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal meningiomas: originates from the meninges, benign brain tumors presenting with headaches, seizures, vomiting, personality changes, and cognitive impairment. Given below is a Coronal MRI section.

 

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: is the most common benign tumor of nasopharynx. Patients present with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Pseudotumor of the orbit: is an idiopathic inflammation of the orbit presenting with painful proptosis, diplopia, and orbital congestion. Imaging shows right medial rectus muscle which is diffusely enlarged with moderate homogeneous enhancement with relative involvement of its tendinous insertion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal mucoceles are a significant cause of proptosis and orbital symptoms, particularly following a history of facial trauma or sinus disease. Prompt diagnosis and surgical intervention to decompress the sinus and restore drainage can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the given image: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Maxillary sinus

 

Marked structure is Maxillary sinus on a non-contrast CT.

 

The Maxillary sinus is one of the largest of the paranasal sinuses and is located in the maxillary bone under the eyes, bilaterally to the nasal cavity. On imaging, such as a non-contrast CT scan, the maxillary sinus is typically visible as a large, air-filled space below the orbits (eye sockets) and lateral to the nasal cavity.

 

Following images show paranasal sinuses and related structures:

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ethmoid Sinus: Located between the nose and the eyes, within the ethmoid bone. It is a collection of small air cells.
  • Frontal Sinus: Located above the eyes, in the frontal bone. These are typically well above the maxillary sinuses.
  • Sphenoid Sinus: Located deeper and more centrally behind the nasal cavity, in the sphenoid bone.
  • Maxillary Sinus: Located beneath the orbits, on either side of the nose.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for diagnosing suspected lateral sinus thrombosis? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laugier’s Sign

 

Explanation:

 

Laugier's sign is not used for diagnosing lateral sinus thrombosis. It is actually a sign associated with fracture of the zygomatic arch, where tenderness is elicited on pressing the fractured fragments. This sign has no relationship to lateral sinus thrombosis or any other otological condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Queckenstedt's Test: This is correctly associated with lateral sinus thrombosis diagnosis. Also called the Tobey-Ayer test, it involves compression of the jugular vein while monitoring CSF pressure via lumbar puncture. In lateral sinus thrombosis, compression of the affected side's jugular vein causes no change in CSF pressure, while compression of the normal side increases CSF pressure.

 

Option B. Crowe-Beck Test: This is correctly used for diagnosing lateral sinus thrombosis. It is an alternative to Queckenstedt's test that avoids lumbar puncture. It involves observing retinal vein engorgement through fundoscopy during jugular compression. With lateral sinus thrombosis, compression of the affected side causes no retinal vein engorgement, while compression of the normal side does.

 

Option C. Griesinger's Sign: This is correctly associated with lateral sinus thrombosis. It refers to edema and tenderness over the mastoid emissary vein (posterior to the mastoid process), which occurs due to thrombophlebitis extending from the lateral sinus to the emissary vein.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While Queckenstedt's test, Crowe-Beck test, and Griesinger's sign are all valid diagnostic indicators for lateral sinus thrombosis, Laugier's sign is unrelated and specifically associated with zygomatic arch fractures.

questions.text: Ohngren's classification and Ohngren's line are related to: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maxillary Sinus Carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Ohngren's classification and Ohngren's line are specifically used in the staging and prognostication of maxillary sinus carcinoma. Ohngren's line is an imaginary plane drawn from the medial canthus of the eye to the angle of the mandible. This line divides the maxillary sinus into anteroinferior and posterosuperior portions, which has significant prognostic implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebellopontine angle tumor: These tumors are classified using different systems related to their location in the posterior cranial fossa. Ohngren's line has no relevance to cerebellopontine angle tumors, which include acoustic neuromas and meningiomas.

 

Option C. Glomus Jugulare Tumor: These tumors are classified based on their extension from the jugular foramen and involvement of surrounding structures. The Fisch classification system is typically used, not Ohngren's classification.

 

Option D. Basal Cell Carcinoma of eyelid: These tumors are classified according to their histopathological features and TNM staging. Ohngren's line is not used in the classification or prognostication of basal cell carcinomas.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ohngren's line is a critical prognostic indicator in maxillary sinus carcinoma; tumors situated posterosuperior to this line (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those anteroinferior to it (infrastructural) due to their proximity to vital structures.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

  •  Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.
  •  Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.
  • Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.
  •  Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A post-COVID patient, who is a known diabetic, develops unilateral facial pain and loosening of teeth. Which investigation would you do to confirm the diagnosis on this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biopsy with histopathologic examination

 

The given scenario of a post-COVID diabetic patient with facial pain and loosening of teeth is suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. Among the given options, Biopsy with histopathologic examination would be the investigation for definitive diagnosis on this patient.

 

The primary reason that appears to be facilitating Mucorales spores to germinate in people with COVID-19 is

 

  1.  An ideal environment of low oxygen (hypoxia)
  2. high glucose (diabetes, new-onset hyperglycemia, steroid-induced hyperglycemia)
  3. Acidic medium (metabolic acidosis, diabetic ketoacidosis [DKA])
  4. High iron levels (increased ferritins)
  5. Decreased phagocytic activity of white blood cells (WBC) due to immunosuppression (SARS-CoV-2 mediated, steroid-mediated or background comorbidities) coupled with several other shared risk factors including prolonged hospitalization with or without mechanical ventilators

 

Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus.

 

The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. Due to invasion of the blood vessels, mucor fungus causes ischemic necrosis presenting as a black eschar, involving inferior turbinate, palate or the sinus. It can later spread to the frontal lobe of the brain and cavernous sinus.

 

 

 

Confirmation of diagnosis is by biopsy and histopathologic examination which shows aseptate fungi with thick-walled, ribbon-like, hyphae branching at right angles.

 

 

MRI is more sensitive to detecting orbital and nervous involvement than CT.

 

Contrast-enhanced MRI is the imaging technique of choice – black turbinate sign is seen

 

 

Post-contrast T1-weighted coronal MR image shows non enhancing soft tissue, “black turbinate sign,” within the left maxillary sinus (asterisk). The mucosa of the inferior turbinate and a portion of the left middle turbinate demonstrate focal lack of the enhancement (arrowheads).

 

Management

 

  • Antifungal therapy with Amphotericin B
  •  Surgical debridement of the affected tissues.
  •  Treatment of underlying cause
  • Control of blood sugars in diabetic patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): Useful for assessing the extent of disease, especially in identifying orbital and central nervous system involvement. It provides detailed images that help in planning the extent of surgical debridement.

 

Option C. Serum Ferritin: Elevated ferritin levels are commonly seen in mucormycosis due to the fungus’s use of iron from the host, which aids its growth. While not diagnostic, high ferritin levels can support the suspicion of mucormycosis in the right clinical context.

 

Option D. HbA1c (Glycated Hemoglobin): This test reflects long-term glucose control and is crucial in managing diabetic patients. Although it does not diagnose mucormycosis, poor glycemic control indicated by a high HbA1c value is a risk factor for the development of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are critical for patients suspected of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis, especially in those with risk factors like diabetes and a recent COVID-19 infection. A biopsy with histopathologic examination is essential for confirming the diagnosis. This condition requires a multidisciplinary approach involving antifungal therapy, surgical debridement, and meticulous management of underlying conditions like diabetes to prevent serious complications and improve outcomes.

questions.text:
Cochlear implantation is not indicated in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Otosclerosis
  2. Congenital hearing loss
  3. Fixed malleus
  4. Ototoxicity induced hearing loss
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 3

 

Cochlear implantation is not indicated in otosclerosis and fixed malleus because these are conductive hearing loss conditions that can be effectively treated with surgical correction. Cochlear implants are designed specifically for sensorineural hearing loss where the cochlear hair cells are damaged but the auditory nerve remains intact.

 

1. Otosclerosis: Otosclerosis involves abnormal bone growth around the stapes footplate, causing fixation and conductive hearing loss. This condition is best treated with stapedectomy or stapedotomy, which directly addresses the mechanical problem by replacing or bypassing the fixed stapes. Success rates for stapedectomy exceed 90% for hearing improvement.

 

3. Fixed malleus: Fixed malleus also causes conductive hearing loss due to mechanical fixation of the ossicular chain. This condition is treated with ossiculoplasty or malleus fixation release procedures that restore normal sound transmission through the middle ear. These surgical interventions directly correct the underlying mechanical problem and can restore near-normal hearing.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

2. Congenital hearing loss: Cochlear implant IS indicated here. This is actually a major indication for cochlear implantation, especially for pre-lingual deaf children (age limit 6 years) where hearing aid trial for 6 months shows no improvement in speech development.

 

4. Ototoxicity induced hearing loss: Cochlear implant IS indicated here. Ototoxic drugs like aminoglycosides (neomycin, gentamicin), chemotherapy agents (cisplatin, carboplatin), diuretics (furosemide, bumetanide), and antimalarials (quinine, chloroquine) cause permanent damage to outer hair cells in the cochlea. When this damage is severe and irreversible, cochlear implantation is the treatment of choice.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cochlear implants are contraindicated in middle ear pathologies that can be surgically corrected.

questions.text: Mucormycosis can be caused by following except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Broad spectrum antibiotics

 

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungal infection. This invades very rapidly to the surrounding tissue and even into orbit and then cranium, black eschars are formed.

 

It can be life-threatening if not attended immediately with surgical debridement, FESS and anti-fungal (Amphotericin-B) medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neutropenia: This condition involves a lowered count of neutrophils, a type of white blood cell that helps prevent and fight infections, making the body more vulnerable to fungal infections.

 

Option B. Uncontrolled Diabetes: High blood sugar levels can impair neutrophil function, making diabetics particularly susceptible to fungal infections like mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Prolonged or High-Dose Corticosteroid Therapy: Steroids suppress the immune system and reduce the body's ability to fight off fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk factors for mucormycosis are:

 

  • Uncontrolled diabetes
  • Prolonged or high-dose corticosteroid therapy
  • Post - organ transplantation
  • Neutropenia
  • Intravenous drug use
  • Prolonged hospitalization
  • Immunodeficiency

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient with diabetes arrived at the clinic with a concerning issue - a black, malodorous discharge originating from her nose. Upon examination, it was discovered that the nasal cavity contained a dark necrotic mass, which had caused erosion of both the septum and hard palate. What could be the most likely diagnosis for this condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucormycosis

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Mucormycosis.

 

It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.

 

PATHOLOGY – From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain. The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES – Black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.

 

DIAGNOSIS – Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.

 

Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast MRI.

 

TREATMENT – Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillosis: While Aspergillosis can also present with sinus involvement, it generally does not cause the rapidly progressive and destructive changes typical of mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Foreign Body: Would not typically lead to rapid tissue necrosis unless secondarily infected, and does not generally produce the black necrotic tissue associated with fungal infections.

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis: Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi; presents with polypoid masses in the nasal passage, distinct from the necrotic presentation of mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis should be considered a medical emergency in immunocompromised patients presenting with signs of rapid, invasive sinus infection. Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are crucial to improve survival rates in affected individuals.

choices.text: It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases
It shows Ad type of curve

questions.text: A patient has otitis media with effusion. Which of the following is wrong?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It shows Ad type of curve

 

Otitis media with effusion (OME) is a condition characterized by the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs or symptoms of acute ear infection. The incorrect statement regarding it is, It shows Ad type of curve. This statement is incorrect. OME typically shows a B type of tympanogram curve. A B type curve indicates the presence of middle ear fluid. An Ad type curve is associated with ossicular discontinuity, which is not related to OME.

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bilateral: Can be true but not mandatory; OME can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Option B. It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases: True, as the condition often resolves with the resolution of the underlying URTI.

 

Option C. It is associated with cold: True, as URTI and colds can lead to Eustachian tube dysfunction and subsequent fluid accumulation in the middle ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otitis media with effusion shows a B type of tympanogram curve, not an Ad type curve.

questions.text: Which structures pass between superior and middle constrictor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal Nerve)

 

The pharyngeal constrictor muscles are organized into three main parts: the superior, middle, and inferior constrictors. Each of these muscles plays a crucial role in the mechanics of swallowing and speech.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passes between the superior and middle constrictor muscles. This is a key anatomical relationship to remember as it is crucial for the nerve supply to the pharynx.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eustachian Tube: Passes through the sinus of Morgagni, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option C. Superior Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the middle and inferior constrictors, not the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option D. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the inferior constrictor and the esophagus, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal nerve) and the stylopharyngeus muscle pass between the superior and middle constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given CT image. (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumatised superior turbinate

 

The superior turbinates form one of the three pairs of conchae in the nose and represent part of the labyrinth of the ethmoid bone, arising as bony projections from its posterior surface.

 

The air passage between the superior nasal concha and the lateral nasal wall is known as the superior meatus and forms part of the nasal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concha bullosa is a pneumatized middle turbinate.

 

 

Option C. Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell/ infraorbital ethmoidal air cells are ethmoid air cells located lateral to the maxillo-ethmoidal suture along the inferomedial orbital floor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumatisation of the superior turbinate, indicates the presence of air spaces within the turbinates, which can have implications for nasal physiology and potential sinus pathologies.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective tests for hearing do not require the active cooperation or response from the patient and are thus particularly useful in non-cooperative subjects such as young children or those who might simulate hearing loss.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system. It evaluates the mobility of the eardrum (tympanic membrane) and the conduction bones of the middle ear, providing useful information about middle ear pressure and fluid presence.

 

Other Option:

 

3. PTA (pure tone audiometry): This is a subjective test as it relies on the patient's response to pure tone stimuli. It is not included as an objective test because it requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. Subjective tests such as PTA, tuning fork tests, and speech audiometry depend on patient interaction and are susceptible to voluntary or involuntary response errors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective hearing tests like BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic information without the need for patient interaction, distinguishing them from subjective tests like Pure Tone Audiometry which rely on patient responses.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked 1 in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fossa of Rosenmuller

 

 

The image represented is the endoscopic view of lateral wall of the nasopharynx. Structure marked 1 is Fossa of Rosenmüller.

1 - FOSSA OF ROSENMULLER

2 - TORUS TUBARIUS

3 - POSTERIOR PHARYNGEAL WALL

4 - EUSTACHIAN TUBE OPENING

Lateral wall of nasopharynx contains Eustachian tube opening in the form of a bulge called torus tubarius and fossa of Rosenmüller lies behind this elevation (most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma)

 

The tubal tonsil is a small lymphoid tissue located at the tubal elevation near the opening of the eustachian tube.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubal Tonsil: Lymphoid tissue near the opening of the Eustachian tube but not visible as marked in this image.

 

Option C. Opening of Eustachian Tube: Located anterior to the Fossa of Rosenmuller, usually at the torus tubarius, not visible in the marked area.

 

Option D. Adenoid: Lymphoid tissue located on the posterior wall of the nasopharynx, not in the lateral wall and thus not visible in this specific view.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Fossa of Rosenmuller's familiarity is essential in nasopharyngeal examinations, especially in the context of identifying potential sites for nasopharyngeal carcinoma or other pathologies. Its recognition during endoscopy guides thorough inspection and appropriate clinical interventions.

questions.text: What is the surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal called? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meatoplasty

 

The surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal is meatoplasty.

 

It is performed in combination with all canal wall down procedures like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for the treatment of middle ear disease such as cholesteatoma. The widened meats help easily visualize and access the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning.

 

It is also done as an isolated procedure in elderly people with sagging auricle. Sagging auricle causes obstruction to the meatus leading to retention of wax and difficulty in hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane for improved hearing.

 

Option C: Myringoplasty refers to the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane only.

 

Option D: A cosmetic or reconstructive procedure aimed at correcting deformities or defects of the external part of the ear (pinna).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meatoplasty is an important surgical option for managing conditions that require improved access to the ear canal and middle ear, particularly in managing chronic ear diseases or anatomical changes that impact ear function.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 32, 457, 463

choices.text: Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. On examination, the doctor diagnose Otosclerosis and recommends stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests based on which the doctor has recommended stapedectomy? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Typical of otosclerosis, indicating conductive hearing loss where BC > AC.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Indicates that the sound is heard better in the ear with more conductive loss, which matches otosclerosis more severely affecting the right ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Indicates that air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC), which is a normal finding and typically not expected in conductive hearing loss like otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: In a case of unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss, Weber's test lateralizes to the better hearing ear in sensorineural hearing loss and to the poorer ear in conductive hearing loss. This pattern does not fit otosclerosis affecting the right ear more severely.

 

Option B. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Again, indicates normal AC > BC, not typical for otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Would suggest either a sensorineural hearing loss on the left ear or less likely conductive loss on the right, which doesn’t match typical otosclerosis findings.

 

Option C. Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Indicates that BC > AC, suggesting conductive hearing loss, typical of otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: Would imply the left ear is either better or has conductive loss, not aligning with greater hearing loss in the right ear due to otosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of a negative Rinne test and Weber test lateralizing to the ear with more hearing loss is indicative of conductive hearing loss in that ear. In otosclerosis, the ossification of the stapes leads to mechanical dysfunction, preventing effective sound transmission, hence a stapedectomy might be recommended to mechanically bypass the ossified stapes and improve hearing.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve

 

The given clinical features of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth are suggestive of paralysis of the facial nerve.

 

Bell's palsy is defined as idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset.

 

Etiology –

 

  1. Viral infection  - herpes simplex, herpes zoster, EBV
  2. Vascular ischemia
  3. Heredity – narrow fallopian canal
  4. Autoimmune

 

Clinical features -

 

Onset is sudden. Patient is unable to close his eyes. On attempting to close the eye, the eyeball turns up and out (Bell phenomenon). Saliva dribbles from the angle of mouth. Face becomes asymmetrical. Tears flow down from the eye (epiphora). Pain in the ear may precede or accompany nerve paralysis. Some complain of noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis) or loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani). Paralysis may be complete or incomplete. Bell palsy is recurrent in 3–10% of patients.

 

 

Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigations.

 

Treatment of Bell's palsy -

 

  • Prednisolone is the drug of choice. If a patient reports within 1 week, the adult dose of prednisolone is 1 mg/kg/day divided into morning and evening doses for 5 days. Patient is seen on the fifth day. If paralysis is incomplete or is recovering, the dose is tapered during the next 5 days. If paralysis remains complete, the same dose is continued for another 10 days and thereafter tapered in next 5 days (total of 20 days).
  • Eye care to prevent keratitis
  • Analgesic for ear pain
  • Physiotherapy

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: Mainly responsible for facial sensation, not motor control.

 

Option C. Oculomotor nerve: Primarily influences eye movement; paralysis typically results in ptosis and pupillary dilation, not facial drooping.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Affects swallowing and taste sensations at the back of the tongue; does not cause facial drooping or affect eye closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prompt recognition and treatment of facial nerve paralysis are crucial for improving outcomes and preventing permanent damage. Treatment primarily involves medication to reduce inflammation and supportive care, especially for eye protection.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 103, 104

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with an extremely painful lesion in the external ear accompanied by otorrhea that has not responded to antibiotics. Granulation tissue is observed in the external ear, and there is evidence of bony erosion along with facial nerve palsy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignant Otitis Externa

 

Explanation:


The clinical presentation strongly indicates Malignant Otitis Externa (MOE), also known as necrotizing otitis externa. Key diagnostic features present in this case include: extreme pain in the external ear, otorrhea unresponsive to antibiotics, presence of granulation tissue in the external ear canal, bony erosion, facial nerve palsy, and importantly, a diabetic patient. MOE is primarily caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection and occurs most commonly in elderly diabetic patients or immunocompromised individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: This typically presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, conductive hearing loss due to eustachian tube dysfunction, and cranial nerve palsies (particularly CN V and VI) from skull base invasion. Primary symptoms would be in the nasopharynx rather than the external ear, and there would not be granulation tissue in the external ear canal.

 

Option C. Chronic suppurative otitis media: This involves a long-standing infection of the middle ear with tympanic membrane perforation and persistent discharge. While it can cause bone erosion and complications like facial palsy, it wouldn't present with granulation tissue in the external ear canal as the primary site of disease is the middle ear. The extreme pain described is also more characteristic of MOE.

 

Option D. Acute suppurative otitis media: This is an acute infection of the middle ear presenting with otalgia, fever, and sometimes otorrhea if the tympanic membrane ruptures. It doesn't cause bony erosion or facial nerve palsy in its typical presentation, and would generally respond to appropriate antibiotic therapy, unlike the case described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Malignant otitis externa should be strongly suspected in elderly diabetic patients presenting with severe otalgia, otorrhea unresponsive to therapy, granulation tissue in the ear canal, and complications like facial nerve palsy or evidence of bony erosion.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Biopsy done under L/A

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular benign tumor that exclusively affects adolescent males. Biopsy is absolutely contraindicated in JNA because it is a vascular tumor with absent contractile muscular components in blood vessel walls. Any attempt to perform a biopsy (whether punch biopsy, needle biopsy, or any other form) will result in profuse, uncontrollable bleeding that is extremely difficult to manage. This is a fundamental in managing vascular tumors - never biopsy suspected JNA, glomus tumors, or hemangiomas.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Recurrent epistaxis: This is correct for JNA. Profuse, recurrent nosebleeds are the hallmark presentation of JNA, often described as heavy nasal bleeding that cannot be controlled by regular clinical measures.

 

Option B. Unilateral nasal obstruction: This is correct for JNA. The tumor typically causes progressive nasal obstruction, which can be unilateral initially but may become bilateral as the tumor grows.

 

Option C. Exclusively adolescent male: This is correct for JNA. This tumor has a unique demographic pattern, occurring only in adolescent males, making this a pathognomonic feature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biopsy is contraindicated in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma due to risk of uncontrollable hemorrhage.



Note -

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors and moving towards the cortex: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Auditory Cortex
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Cochlear Nucleus
  4. Lateral leminiscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Olivary complex
  7. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-3-6-4-5-7-1

 

The correct sequence of structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors (cochlea) and moving towards the auditory cortex, is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion: The auditory nerve fibers originate here.

 

3. Cochlear Nucleus: The auditory nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

6. Olivary complex: After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary complex.

 

4. Lateral lemniscus: From the superior olivary complex, the auditory signals travel via the lateral lemniscus.

 

5. Inferior colliculus: The lateral lemniscus projects to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

7. Medial geniculate body: The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

1. Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals reach the auditory cortex (Area 41) in the temporal lobe for processing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

AUDITORY PATHWAY

 

E – Eighth nerve

 

C – Cochlear nucleus

 

O – Olivary complex (superior)

 

L – Lateral lemniscus

 

I – Inferior colliculus

 

M – Medial geniculate body

 

A – Auditory cortex

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

 

The clinical picture is suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

 

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal injury is commonly seen in total thyroidectomy.

 

  • Injury to both RLNs results in paralysis of intrinsic muscles of the larynx. The vocal cords cannot be abducted and thus come to lie in a median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid. This results in compromised laryngeal airway causing respiratory distress and stridor.
  • Tracheostomy is done as an emergency procedure to secure the airway.
  • Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:
    1. Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)
    2. Partial arytenoidectomy
    3. Reinnervation procedures - these are used to innervate paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.
    4.  Thyroplasty type II – lateralisation of vocal cords

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Superior laryngeal nerve injury - This would primarily affect voice pitch and not typically cause significant breathing difficulty.

 

Option B. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury - Would lead to hoarseness but not usually severe breathing issues as one vocal cord would still function.

 

Option D. Hematoma - Although it can cause acute respiratory distress if it compresses the trachea, it does not typically lead to issues with extubation unless it is very severe.

 

Educational Objective:


Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury after thyroidectomy is a serious complication that can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. Immediate recognition and management are crucial to ensure the safety and recovery of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 339

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auricular branch of vagus

 

Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

 

Nerve supply of external auditory canal

 

External Auditory Canal

 

  1. Anterior wall and roof: auriculotemporal (V3).
  2. Posterior wall and floor: auricular branch of vagus (CN X) aka Arnolds nerve
  3. Posterior wall of the auditory canal also receives sensory fibres of CN VII through auricular branch of vagus

 

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): Stimulation of Arnold's nerve in the external auditory canal during wax removal evokes reflex cough.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve - Provides sensation to the anterior wall and roof of the canal, not typically associated with triggering cough.

 

Option C. Great auricular nerve - Primarily involved in the sensation of the skin around the ear, not the inner canal.

 

Option D. Facial nerve - While it contributes sensory fibers, it is not the primary cause of the cough reflex in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ear-cough reflex is a unique physiological reaction mediated by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve, illustrating the interconnectedness of sensory pathways and autonomic responses in the human body.

questions.text:
Which of the following tests can be used if otoacoustic emissions is absent for screening?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure tone audiometry
  2. Tympanometry
  3. Free field audiometry
  4. Speech audiometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 4

 

When otoacoustic emissions (OAE) are absent, it indicates a potential cochlear pathology, specifically affecting the outer hair cells. Further testing is required to assess the extent and nature of hearing loss, as well as to rule out any retrocochlear pathology.

 

2. Tympanometry: This test assesses the condition of the middle ear and tympanic membrane mobility by creating variations in air pressure in the ear canal. It is useful to determine if the absence of OAEs might be related to middle ear issues, such as fluid, which can mask cochlear function.

 

4. Speech Audiometry: This test evaluates the ability to understand speech and also provides information about the clarity of speech perception. It helps to determine the speech recognition threshold and is crucial for diagnosing the degree and type of hearing loss when OAEs are absent.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure Tone Audiometry: While this test is crucial for determining the threshold levels of hearing and the degree of hearing loss across different frequencies, it was not specified as one of the correct responses in this context.

 

3. Free Field Audiometry: Generally used for young children or individuals who cannot reliably use headphones, this test measures hearing sensitivity to sounds presented in an open field. However, it requires a controlled sound field, which is not always practical for immediate follow-up when OAEs are absent.

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 29

choices.text: Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of high tracheostomy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

 

A high tracheostomy is done above the level of thyroid isthmus (isthmus lies against II, III and IV tracheal rings). It violates the first ring of trachea. Tracheostomy at this site can cause perichondritis of the cricoid cartilage and subglottic stenosis and is always avoided.

 

Only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx because in such cases, the total larynx anyway would ultimately be removed and a fresh tracheostome made in a clean area lower down.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord palsy - Not an indication for high tracheostomy as it does not necessitate altering the anatomy at the level of the isthmus or above.

 

Option B. Tracheomalacia - This condition, characterized by a weakness of the tracheal support cartilage, does not require a high tracheostomy. Treatment usually involves support lower in the trachea.

 

Option C. Foreign body obstruction - Removal of a foreign body typically does not require a high tracheostomy. This procedure would be too high to effectively clear an obstruction that is likely situated lower in the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High tracheostomy is specifically indicated for suspicion of laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery, as this condition requires eventual removal of the larynx, allowing for the creation of a fresh tracheostome in a new, clean area.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 359

choices.text: Failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along posterior metal wall
Widening of meatus and facial nerve palsy might be seen

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about keratosis obturans? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

All of the above statements are true regarding keratosis obturans.

 

  • Collection of a pearly white mass of desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus is called keratosis obturans. This, by its pressure effect, causes absorption of bone leading to widening of the meatus so much so that facial nerves may be exposed and paralyzed.
  • Presenting symptoms may be pain in the ear, hearing loss, tinnitus and sometimes ear discharge. It may sometimes be associated with bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis.
  • On examination, the ear canal may be full of pearly white mass of keratin material disposed in several layers. Removal of this mass may show widening of bony meatus with ulceration and even granuloma formation.

 

 

Treatment

 

Keratotic mass is removed either by syringing or instrumentation, similar to the techniques employed for impacted wax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratosis obturans is characterized by the accumulation of epithelial cells in the ear canal, leading to potential structural damage and associated symptoms. Its management requires careful removal of the buildup and monitoring for complications such as facial nerve palsy. Awareness of its association with bronchiectasis and sinusitis is crucial for comprehensive patient care.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image. (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenoid facies

 

The above given image shows adenoid facies. The characteristic features are visible which are: -

 

  • Elongated face with dull expression
  • Open mouth
  • Hitched up upper lip
  • Prominent upper teeth, which appear crowded
  • High arched hard palate
  • Pinched-in nose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goldenhar syndrome: Typically presents with abnormalities of the eye, ear, and spine, none of which are visible in this image.

 

Option C. Horse facies: Characterized by an elongated face with prominent jaw structures, which does not match the features in the image.

 

Option D. Frog facies: Often includes a wide mouth and bulging eyes, which are not present in this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoid facies can be recognized by characteristic features such as elongated face, open mouth posture due to nasal obstruction, hitched up upper lip revealing crowded upper teeth, and a pinched-in nose. It's associated with chronic adenoid hypertrophy, impacting the facial structure and respiratory function.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS (Functional endoscopic sinus surgery) for failed conservative management 5 years ago. Uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation was done during the previous FESS. A DNE done now shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroid irrigation and antihistamines

 

The next best step in management in this patient is steroid irrigation and antihistamines.

 

This patient who had previously undergone FESS 5 years ago for failed medical management now has nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip suggestive of acute rhinosinusitis.

 

Acute rhinosinusitis usually develops along with viral upper respiratory tract infection due to mucosal swelling causing obstruction of the sinus ostia. Persistent or worsening symptoms even after 10 days with fever and purulent discharge indicates secondary bacterial infection.

 

Treatment initially is symptomatic with -

 

  • First line of treatment - Nasal steroid irrigation, decongestants, and antihistamines
  • In cases of secondary bacterial infection antibiotics are indicated. Amoxyclav is the drug of choice.
  • Biological therapy is not used in the treatment of sinusitis. It may be used in cases of refractory polyp.
  • Revision surgery is indicated only when maximal medical therapy has failed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat Surgery: Indicated only if there are anatomical obstructions or complications that cannot be managed medically. In this case, the DNE shows patent ostia, so repeat surgery is not indicated without further evidence of structural issues.

 

Option B. Macrolides for 4 months: Could be considered for their anti-inflammatory properties in some chronic rhinosinusitis cases, but there is no mention of bacterial infection needing long-term antibiotics, making this less suitable than symptomatic management.

 

Option D. Biological Therapy: Mainly used for refractory cases with specific underlying conditions such as severe asthma or nasal polyps, which is not indicated here based on the provided scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip post-FESS with no current acute infection or structural issues, conservative management using steroid irrigation and antihistamines is recommended to manage inflammation and alleviate symptoms.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 213, 214

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea and vomiting. On investigation, there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meniere’s disease

The patient's symptoms and the diagnostic finding of endolymphatic hypertension align with Meniere's disease. 

Characterized by episodes of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, lasting from minutes to hours. The symptoms are due to the accumulation of fluid in the inner ear (endolymphatic hydrops), leading to increased pressure within the endolymphatic system.

Other Options:

 Option B. Otosclerosis: A condition primarily affecting the bones of the middle ear, particularly the stapes. It causes conductive hearing loss, not typically associated with vertigo or tinnitus of the type seen in Meniere’s disease.

Option C. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV): Characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to changes in head position. It involves the dislodgment of otoliths within the inner ear, leading to brief, intense episodes of vertigo, without the auditory symptoms typical of Meniere's disease. 

Option D. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma): A benign tumor on the vestibular nerve, leading to progressive, unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances. It usually does not cause episodic vertigo like Meniere's disease.

Educational Objective:

Meniere’s disease is a chronic condition that requires management of symptoms through lifestyle changes, medications to control vertigo, and sometimes more invasive treatments to manage fluid pressure in the inner ear.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with vertigo, tinnitus and fluctuating hearing loss. The audiogram is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given image? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meniere’s disease

 

Given the patient's symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss, along with the audiogram showing a sensorineural hearing loss pattern with a dip at low to mid frequencies, the most likely diagnosis is Option B, Meniere’s disease.

 

Meniere’s disease is characterized by episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. The audiogram typically shows a sensorineural hearing loss that predominantly affects the low to mid frequencies, which is consistent with the audiogram provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo): Is a disorder arising from a problem in the inner ear. Symptoms include vertigo that is usually triggered by changes in the position of the head. It doesn't typically cause hearing loss, which we can see in the audiogram.

 

Option C. Vestibular neuronitis: Is an inflammation of the vestibular nerve, leading to vertigo and imbalance, but it does not usually affect hearing, so the audiogram would not show the hearing loss pattern we see here.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: Is a middle ear disease that usually presents with conductive hearing loss, particularly in younger adults, and it does not cause vertigo or tinnitus as primary symptoms. The audiogram for otosclerosis would show an air-bone gap, which is not present in the audiogram provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating hearing loss, and an audiogram showing low to mid frequency sensorineural hearing loss is Meniere’s disease.

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis
