questions.text: Which of the following is part of trotter's triad, seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma? (FMGE DECEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Conductive hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

 

TROTTER'S TRIAD:

 

  • ﻿﻿Conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction. Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia (CN V mandibular branch)
  • ﻿﻿Palatal paralysis

 

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 285

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not cause conductive hearing loss? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endolymphatic Hydrops

 

Explanation:


Endolymphatic hydrops is the pathological condition underlying Ménière's disease. It involves an excessive accumulation of endolymph in the inner ear's membranous labyrinth, particularly affecting the cochlea. This condition causes sensorineural hearing loss (not conductive) because it affects the sensory hair cells in the cochlea. The hearing loss in Ménière's disease is typically fluctuating and predominantly affects the lower frequencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otosclerosis: This condition causes conductive hearing loss. Otosclerosis involves abnormal bone formation around the stapes footplate, leading to its fixation in the oval window. This prevents normal transmission of sound vibrations from the middle ear to the inner ear, resulting in conductive hearing loss of up to 60 dB.

 

Option B. Serous otitis media: This condition causes conductive hearing loss. Also known as otitis media with effusion, it involves accumulation of non-purulent fluid in the middle ear space. This fluid impedes the movement of the tympanic membrane and ossicular chain, resulting in conductive hearing loss typically ranging from 20-40 dB.

 

Option D. Suppurative otitis media: This condition causes conductive hearing loss. Acute or chronic suppurative otitis media involves infection of the middle ear with purulent discharge. The presence of pus in the middle ear and/or perforation of the tympanic membrane interferes with sound transmission, resulting in conductive hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Endolymphatic hydrops (Ménière's disease) is an inner ear disorder causing sensorineural hearing loss, while conditions affecting the external or middle ear (otosclerosis, otitis media) cause conductive hearing loss by interfering with the mechanical transmission of sound to the inner ear.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway:(INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-1-3-4-5

 

The correct sequence of the auditory pathway is spiral ganglion - cochlear nucleus - superior olivary nucleus - inferior colliculus - medial geniculate body.

 

2. Spiral Ganglion : The spiral ganglion is situated in Rosenthal's canal and contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve, which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

 

1. Cochlear Nucleus : The cochlear nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

3. Superior Olivary Nucleus : After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary nucleus.

 

4. Inferior Colliculus : From the superior olivary nucleus, the auditory signals travel to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

5. Medial Geniculate Body : The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA).

 

  1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
  2. Cochlear Nucleus
  3. Superior Olivary nucleus
  4. Lateral lemniscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Medial geniculate body
  7. Auditory cortex

questions.text: An elderly gentleman has presented with symptoms of difficulty swallowing, regurgitation, bad breath, and cough. He also exhibits bilateral lung crepitations upon examination. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zenker's Diverticulum

 

Explanation:

 

Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum where pharyngeal mucosa herniates through Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle). This condition typically affects patients over 60 years of age, matching our elderly patient's demographic. The classic symptoms include dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), regurgitation of undigested food (especially at night when recumbent), halitosis (bad breath), and cough with aspiration pneumonia (explaining the bilateral lung crepitations).

 

Visual Support

 

Zenker's diverticulum occurs when herniation of pouch starts in the midline. It is at first behind the esophagus and then comes to lie on its left. The mouth of the sac is wider than the opening of esophagus, so food preferentially enters the sac.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schatzki Ring: This is a narrow ring of tissue at the lower end of the esophagus and would not cause regurgitation of undigested food or aspiration pneumonia. It typically presents with intermittent dysphagia for solids only, not the constellation of symptoms described.

 

Option C. Corkscrew Esophagus: This is a motility disorder (diffuse esophageal spasm) characterized by non-peristaltic contractions. While it can cause dysphagia, it does not lead to regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia as seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome: This condition is characterized by hypochromic microcytic anemia, dysphagia, and esophageal webs. It typically affects women in their 40s and 50s, not elderly men. It is not associated with regurgitation, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zenker's diverticulum should be suspected in elderly patients presenting with dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, and respiratory complications due to aspiration, as the pouch traps food that can later be regurgitated and aspirated.

choices.text: Partial fixation of footplate of stapes

questions.text: What causes maximum hearing loss? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ossicular discontinuity with intact TM

 

Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane causes maximum hearing loss (around 50 dB) because:

 

  • Sound waves can only travel through the ossicular chain when it is intact
  • When there's a break in the ossicular chain, sound transmission is completely interrupted
  • With intact TM, there's no alternative pathway for sound to reach the inner ear
  • The sound waves get dampened at the point of discontinuity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis media with effusion

 

  • Causes mild conductive hearing loss (30-35 dB)
  • Middle ear filled with serous fluid still allows some sound transmission
  • Common in children with adenoid hypertrophy blocking Eustachian tube

 

Option B. Partial fixation of footplate of stapes

 

  • Represents early otosclerosis
  • Causes mild conductive hearing loss as stapes can still move partially
  • Less severe than complete ossicular discontinuity

 

Option D. Malleus-incus disruption with TM disruption

 

  • Causes around 40 dB hearing loss
  • Less severe than option C because sound waves can reach round window directly through the perforation
  • Provides an alternative pathway for sound transmission

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane causes maximum hearing loss (50 dB) because sound waves have no alternative pathway to reach the inner ear.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with ear wax and was subjected to syringing to remove the wax. She developed a syncopal episode while doing the procedure when the tip of the syringe touched the ear canal. Which of the nerves is responsible for this episode of syncope? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Arnold’s nerve

 

Stimulation of Arnolds nerve (auricular branch of vagus nerve) in the posterior canal wall during wax removal can lead to a vasovagal attack causing syncope.

 

Nerve supply of pinna and EAC: Greater auricular, lesser occipital, auriculotemporal, Arnold’s (auricular branch of Vagus nerve), facial branch.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve: Mainly responsible for sensory innervation around the tragus and adjacent areas, not typically involved in reflexive syncope.

 

Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Primarily involved in the sensations and taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue, and innervation of some muscles of the pharynx, not directly related to ear canal stimulation.

 

Option D. Jacobson's nerve: Involved with the middle ear, carrying fibers that contribute to the tympanic plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Arnold's nerve is crucial in the context of ear procedures, where its stimulation can lead to significant autonomic responses, including syncope. Awareness of this nerve's sensitivity is important for clinicians performing ear syringing or other manipulative treatments involving the ear canal.

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Super supraglottic swallow

 

Super supraglottic swallow is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation but in dysphagia to prevent aspiration of food.

 

The Super-Supraglottic Swallow technique is employed for patients experiencing diminished airway closure. To perform this technique, patients are directed to take a deep breath and tightly hold it while bearing down. They should maintain this breath hold and bear down as they swallow. Immediately after the swallow (before inhaling), they are instructed to cough, followed by a forceful swallow once more (before inhaling). This sequence is aimed at enhancing airway protection during swallowing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP) is a one-way valve inserted through a tracheoesophageal puncture. Occlusion of the stoma shunts the exhaled air through the TEP into the esophagus producing vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter resulting in phonation.

Option B. Esophageal speech is phonation produced by vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter.

 

Option C. Polite yawning also called nasal airflow-inducing maneuver is indicated for olfaction rehabilitation post laryngectomy. This maneuver induces a negative pressure in the oral cavity and oropharynx, which generates a nasal airflow, enabling odorous substances to reach the olfactory epithelium again.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Super supraglottic swallow technique is crucial for enhancing airway protection in dysphagia management but is not utilized in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation, where the focus is primarily on restoring voice and smell functions through other specialized techniques.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition 352, 353; Scott Brown 7th edition, Volume 2, Page No. 2090

choices.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of these options is not a division originating from the external carotid artery within Kiesselbach's plexus? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery which in turn is a branch of internal carotid artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphenopalatine artery: This artery is correctly identified as a branch of the maxillary artery, which itself is a major branch of the external carotid artery. It contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus by providing the septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Option C. Greater palatine artery: Also a branch of the maxillary artery, the septal branch of the greater palatine artery participates in forming Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Option D. Septal branch of superior labial artery: This artery, a branch of the facial artery (which originates from the external carotid artery), is part of the blood supply to Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ARTERIAL SUPPLY OF THE NOSE:

 

Internal carotid system -

 

  • Branches of ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

 

External Carotid System –

 

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).

 

KIESSELBACH'S PLEXUS -

 

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of greater palatine

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: A gentleman presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a past history of cough, on/off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with pale granuloma. His chest x-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleated giant cells, and caseous necrosis. What would be the probable cause? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

Generalized symptoms of fever, productive cough, weight loss, night sweats, and hemoptysis along with chest x-ray showing multiple cavitation lesions are suggestive of tuberculosis. This diagnosis is supported by:

 

  • Chest X-ray: Presence of multiple cavitary lesions, which are characteristic of pulmonary TB.
  • Biopsy Findings: The presence of granulomas, multinucleated giant cells (Langhans type), and caseous necrosis is indicative of TB, which involves granulomatous inflammation with a distinctive type of necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener's Granulomatosis: This could also present with nasal deformity and granulomas but is usually associated with vasculitis and lacks the caseous necrosis typical of TB.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Can cause nasal collapse ("saddle nose") but typically does not present with the lung involvement seen in TB.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Also presents with granulomas but lacks the caseous necrosis seen in TB and typically shows non-cavitary lung lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis should be considered in patients presenting with respiratory symptoms, systemic signs, and nasal deformities when accompanied by histological evidence of caseating granulomas. This constellation of findings is distinct in suggesting TB over other granulomatous diseases.

 

Granulomatous Disease of the Nose:
